Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Advancing Routing Methods in Hazardous Materials Transportation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to advance routing methods in hazardous materials (hazmat) transportation to mitigate the risk of hazmat accidents and provide fundamental building blocks to bring the current research and practice up to the next level. Despite significant advances in risk management theory, current research and practice in hazmat transportation heavily rely on very simple risk measures. This should be unacceptable for risk-averse routing. In addition, a serious issue of data uncertainty has not been well addressed. This project will provide essential theory and algorithms of Spectral Risk Measures (SRM) applied in hazmat transportation, which have the potential to radically change current research and practice in government planning for safer management of infrastructure. This project will deliver routing methods based on the SRM concept under data uncertainty and time dependency. SRM will be shown to be effective in low-probability, high-consequence applications. If successful, this project will provide the most advanced risk mitigation methods for hazmat routing.

Since the research will be tested with real-world cases, the results have great potential to be applied to other real-world hazmat transportation problems. This project will also have an impact on other transportation problems of a similar nature. The risk measure, models, and solution procedures are also applicable to gas-emission reduction, supply-chain disruption management, humanitarian logistics, and the design of reliable networks. This project will also contribute to building research and teaching infrastructures. The web-based simulation system will be used for teaching and testing research ideas, demonstrating the nature of hazmat transportation, and training practitioners. This project will educate and train students from underrepresented groups as well as local high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project advanced the risk mitigation methods for hazardous materials (hazmat) transportation. Techniques and methods from various disciplines, such as financial engineering, mathematical optimization, behavioral economics, game theory, and operations research, have been investigated and integrated to provide managing various uncertainties in hazmat transportation. Key questions regarding uncertainties are as follows. Do we know where in the road network a hazmat accident would more likely happen? Do we know the likely size of accident consequences? Do we know how hazmat carriers would select their routes and respond to government regulations? In most cases, answers are “Yes, somewhat, but not exactly.” This project provided scientific tools for managing risk from such uncertainty and demonstrated their effectiveness in various experiments and case studies. 

 

Any additional robustness to risk results in an increase in operational costs. This project investigated how the new risk measures, namely various spectral risk measures, can provide flexible tools for hazmat routing and infrastructure operations, while limiting cost increases and providing robustness. Case studies demonstrated that we can provide sufficient robustness with marginal cost increases, when the proposed new risk measures and methods are used. When the cost increases and robustness affect hazmat carriers and our citizens inequitably, we can also introduce equity measures in our risk management plans. While such additional equity consideration would increase the total risk in general, this project provided computational tools to minimize such risk increase, while assuring equity in safety and cost.

 

This project trained six doctoral students including three women students and contributed on the diversity of workforces in science, engineering, and technology. The outcome of the project has been disseminated actively via conference presentation and journal publications, two of which received paper awards. The research team reached out to high-school students to inform the important issues of hazmat transportation and infrastructure management. This project also contributed to building education and research infrastructure. A web-based routing tool is developed to help educating high-school and undergraduate students. Five computational packages for the Julia Language are developed and shared openly with the public. The results of the research have been incorporated in the new PhD-level course, titled “Network Modeling, Design, and Optimization,” which has been attended by students in industrial engineering, civil engineering, and computer engineering.
